courses.name: Topics in Animal Science
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course.  Various topics, credit arranged.  There may be prerequisites enforced depending on the topic.

courses.name: Animal Science
courses.description: Principles of animal science including importance of animal agriculture, genetics, anatomy, physiology and nutrition.

courses.name: Animal Science - Honors
courses.description: Principles of animal science including importance of animal agriculture, genetics, anatomy, physiology and nutrition.

courses.name: Introduction to Captive Wild Animal Management
courses.description: (same as F_W 1012). General introduction to housing, husbandry, behavior, genetics, nutrition, reproduction, animal health, and disease control of native and exotic species in zoological parks and other animal conservation facilities; emphasizes the role of captive animals in wildlife conservation.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biotechnology in Animal Agriculture
courses.description: Concepts, discoveries, and applications of biotechnology ranging from the discovery of brewing and baking to animal cloning and genetic engineering are covered.  Students will acquire a foundation to understand how biotechnology affects agriculture and our everyday lives.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Animal Science Laboratory Practicum
courses.description: An introductory course in skill, related to the care and management of livestock and poultry plus a section dealing with meats and a section dealing with research methods.  Students will be expected to participate in hands-on learning development of fundamental skills and animal husbandry.  This class will include one 3 hour lab and 1 hour DIS per week.

courses.name: Topics in Animal Science
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course.  Various topics, credit arranged.  There may be prerequisites enforced depending on the topic.

courses.name: Equine Practicum
courses.description: Focus on learning hands-on equine skills through the care of horses at the university's equine facility.  Experiential learning is emphasized.  Skills include: how to identify the general health and well-being of horses, recognize early onset of illness or lameness, understand basic feeding, housing, and daily care, and demonstrate the ability to handle and feed horses in a safe manner.  Monthly meetings, scheduled feed shifts, monthly journals, required skill assessments, and attendance at various educational activities are required.  Feed shift scheduling is determined around individual availability and no equine or animal experience is required.  To enroll, students should contact the instructor for an application.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Animal Science
courses.description: Library and laboratory study of assigned problems in animal breeding, nutrition, physiology or production and management. Planning, conduction and reporting to be in consultation with instructor.

courses.name: Equine Behavior and Training
courses.description: Students learn the psychology and ethology of equine behavior and how it relates to training.  The use and proper fitting of equipment is taught and students learn to teach horses to perform the basic movements needed prior to advancing to specialized training.

courses.name: Global Animal Agriculture
courses.description: Animal Agriculture as influenced globally by political, religious cultural, economic and climatic factors.

courses.name: Sophomore Seminar: Societal Issues Facing Animal Agriculture
courses.description: Course designed to introduce students to key issues facing animal agriculture. Assignments focus on reading current publications associated with issues affecting the animal agriculture industry. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Sophomore Seminar: Societal Issues Facing Animal Agriculture - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Course designed to introduce students to key issues facing animal agriculture. Assignments focus on reading current publications associated with issues affecting the animal agriculture industry. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Live Animal and Meat Evaluation
courses.description: (same as F_S 2114). The composition and quality meat produced from food animals is the driving component of livestock economic value. This course will teach the principles and procedures involved in evaluation, grading, selection, and economic value of meat animals and poultry and the carcasses they produce. This course is an excellent introduction and (or) prerequisite for all livestock production courses and will provide a baseline of information for students interested in livestock or meat judging.

courses.name: Livestock Judging
courses.description: Comparative judging and evaluation; various classes of farm animals; particular reference to utility. Reference reading; illustrated lectures.

courses.name: Dairy Products Evaluation
courses.description: (same as F_S 2131) Sensory Evaluation and judging of dairy products.

courses.name: Horse Selection and Evaluation
courses.description: Techniques of selecting and evaluating horses based on conformation and performance characteristics. Effects of conformation on soundness. Includes learning to organize observations on the relative merits of a group of horses into an oral presentation.

courses.name: Companion Animals
courses.description: (same as BIOMED 2140). Focus on companion dog, cat, and horse owners concerns re: health zoonoses, legal responsibilities, inbreeding, choice of breeds, behavioral problems and loss of companion animals.

courses.name: Introduction to Ruminant Livestock Production
courses.description: This is an introductory theory course which provides fundamental understanding of ruminant livestock - beef cattle and diary cattle, production, management and associate industries. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Monogastric Production
courses.description: Introductory course which provides fundamental understanding of hogs, horses and poultry. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Equine Facility Management and Marketing
courses.description: Focuses on learning equine facility management through student care and management of the University's equine facility and breeding herd. Students also learn handling techniques for a wide variety of horses and gain experience in general equine facility maintenance. Students will be responsible for marketing horses sold in the annual MU online horse auction. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: AN_SCI 2135 and instructor's consent.  Cannot be taken at the same time as AN_SCI 2095

courses.name: Topics in Animal Science
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course.  Various topics, credit arranged.  There may be prerequisites enforced depending on the topic.

courses.name: Problems in Animal Science
courses.description: Current problems in animal breeding, nutrition, livestock production and management, meats. Assigned topics. In some cases student may undertake a project by outlining objectives, planning work, keeping records and summarizing results in written report. Some sections may be graded either on S/U or A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Animal Science - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Current problems in animal breeding, nutrition, livestock production and management, meats. Assigned topics. In some cases student may undertake a project by outlining objectives, planning work, keeping records and summarizing results in written report. Some sections may be graded either on S/U or A-F basis only.

courses.name: Study Abroad: International Meat, Dairy and Enology
courses.description: (same as F_S 3190).  This study abroad course introduces students to the meat, dairy and wine industries in Germany or in New Zealand (destinations are on a rotational basis).  Students will visit small, medium and large-scale producers and learn about differences in comparisons to the US industries.  May be repeated once for credit.

courses.name: Principles of Animal Nutrition
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to teach students the essential nutrients for animal life and to understand the basic principles of nutrition. Graded on A-F basis only.  Recommend:  1 course in biochemistry or at least 4 hours of chemistry and MATH 1100 or equivalent.

courses.name: Genetics of Agricultural Plants and Animals
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 3213). Concepts of molecular, transmission, and population and quantitative genetics. Special emphasis given to breeding and biotechnological applications in plant and animal agriculture.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 and one of the following: BIO_SC 1100 (or F_W 1100) or BIO_SC 1200 or BIO_SC 1500.

courses.name: Principles of Meat Science
courses.description: (same as F_S 3214). Study of the principles involved in the conversion of living animals to meat and by-products; efficient utilization of meat as a food.

courses.name: Principles of Dairy Foods Science
courses.description: (same as F_S 3231). Technology, chemistry and microbiology related to milk and its transformation into fluid milk products, fermented dairy foods and spreads. (2 hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.)
courses.recommendation: One course in Chemistry or Biological Sciences

courses.name: Animal Feeds and Feeding
courses.description: Description of feed ingredients, formulation of diets, and animal feeding management.

courses.name: Principles and Applications of Animal Nutrition
courses.description: Fundamentals of animal nutrition, including digestion, absorption, metabolism, and function of nutrients; nutrient and energy requirements; feedstuffs used in livestock and companion animal nutrition; and integration of these principles with nutrition-based calculations to make nutritional management decisions. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or higher, CHEM 1320 or higher, Sophomore standing or higher

courses.name: Physiology of Domestic Animals
courses.description: A lecture and laboratory course that covers basic concepts of physiology and anatomy in vertebrate animals.
courses.prerequisites: F_W 1100 or BIO_SC 1100 or BIO_SC 1500; CHEM 1320; MATH 1100

courses.name: Physiology of Domestic Animals - Honors
courses.description: Basic concepts of physiology and anatomy as related to domestic animals.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 and BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500; CHEM 1310 and CHEM 1320; Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Physiology of Domestic Animals Laboratory
courses.description: This laboratory course covers the basic concepts of physiology as related to domestic animals.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 and BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500; CHEM 1310 and CHEM 1320; AN_SCI 3254 or equivalent

courses.name: Meat Animal Evaluation
courses.description: Meat animal evaluation highlights the relationships and limitations that exist when evaluating market and breeding animals and develops an appreciation for carcass excellence as it relates to production, merchandising and consumption. Some travel time and commitments will be necessary.

courses.name: Topics in Animal Science
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course. Various topics, credit arranged.

courses.name: Topics in Animal Science - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course. Various topics, credit arranged.

courses.name: Pasture-Based Dairy Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7010). The objective of the class is to give a broad overview of pasture-based dairying and instill a confidence for students evaluating if this type of animal agriculture is an occupation they want to pursue after graduation. The class is taught by experts from various departments in CAFNR and covers elements of dairy and forage production needed to be successful.  Materials from this class are also cross-species related where information can be used on other ruminant type operations.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Background in dairy production, nutrition and reproductive physiology for Animal Science students or plant physiology and forage production for Plant Science students

courses.name: Pasture Based Dairy Management Lab
courses.description: This course is a hands-on experience class taught over 4 days during spring break. The objective of the class is to give a broad overview of pasture-based dairying and instill a confidence for students evaluating if this type of animal agriculture is an occupation they want to pursue after graduation. The class is taught by experts from various departments in CAFNR and covers elements of dairy and forage production needed to be successful. Students will have the opportunity to interact with successful pasture-based dairy producers in Missouri and apply their experience from AN_SCI 4010 on real farm situations. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Monogastric Nutrition
courses.description: (same as NEP 4020; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7312 and NUTRIT 7020). Principles of nutrition, feed formulation and recent research in poultry feeding. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physiology of Reproduction
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7314). Principles of animal reproduction with emphasis on endocrine control of reproductive processes.

courses.name: Physiology of Reproduction - Honors
courses.description: Principles of animal reproduction with emphasis on endocrine control of reproductive processes.

courses.name: Applied Livestock Genetics
courses.description: Genetic principles applied to improvement of farm animals. Covers selection, prediction of genetic merit and mating systems. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500 and  MATH 1100

courses.name: Genomics of Plants and Animals
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7324). Analysis of organisms at the level of the complete genome sequence.  Covers genome sequencing, assembly and annotation, as well as functional, evolutionary and computational genomics.
courses.recommendation: BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500, MATH 1100, AN_SCI 3213 /PLNT_S 3213 or equivalent

courses.name: Ruminant Nutrition
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7332). Physiology, chemistry, microbiology and pathology of ruminants. Emphasizes the digestion, absorption, metabolism and utilization of nutrients.

courses.name: Processing Muscle Foods
courses.description: (same as F_S 4344; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7344). Materials and technologies for the manufacture of muscle food products from red meats, poultry and seafood. Experience problem-solving through further processing of complex ingredients and develop skills by practicing operations in a pilot plant facility.

courses.name: Physiology and Biochemistry of Muscle as Food
courses.description: (same as F_S 4354; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7354). Basic concepts in muscle growth and development of livestock evaluating the effects of environment, welfare, nutrition and genetics regarding muscle metabolism, physiology, and the ultimate condition of muscle as food.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or equivalent or AN_SCI 3214 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Reproductive Management
courses.description: Reproductive management of cattle, swine and sheep; estrous synchronization; artificial insemination; embryo development and transfer; assisted reproductive technologies.
courses.prerequisites: senior standing and AN_SCI 4314 and instructor's consent

courses.name: Equine Reproduction
courses.description: Focuses on reproductive management techniques and breeding in the horse. Topics include stallion collection and evaluation, artificial insemination, interpreting ultrasound images, teasing, parturition, and foal care. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 3254 and AN_SCI 4314 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Equine Breeding Management
courses.description: Focuses on practical applications of reproductive management techniques and breeding in the horse.  Topics include stallion collection and evaluation, artificial insemination, interpreting ultrasound images, teasing, parturition, and foal care.  Students will gain hands-on experience in each of these areas.

courses.name: Environmental Physiology
courses.description: Principles of environmental physiology and animal adaptation with emphasis on mechanisms of temperature regulation and related nutritional and metabolic-hormonal functions.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Captive Wild Animal Management
courses.description: (same as F_W 4910). Investigates key issues in captive wild animal management, focusing on the role of animal caretakers in addressing the issues.  Students are required to formulate informed opinions regarding these topics and communicate effectively about the subject matter. Graded A-F only.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1012 or F_W 1012 or instructor's consent; junior or senior standing

courses.name: Internship in Animal Science & Technology
courses.description: Off-campus training to develop technical skills and understanding of an area of animal science. Written reports required. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Animal Science
courses.description: Individually directed field or laboratory research culminating in a poster or oral presentation for upper-class students under faculty supervision.
courses.prerequisites: At least sophomore standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Molecular and Cellular Techniques in Animal Science
courses.description: A directed research project that employs current molecular and cellular technologies. Students will generate experimental data, analyze the data and draft a research report in the format of a scientific paper.
courses.recommendation: an introductory course in biology and a course in organic chemistry, at least junior standing

courses.name: Beef Production and Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SIC 7975). Systems of beef production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred beef cattle.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Beef Production and Management - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SIC 7975). Systems of beef production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred beef cattle.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Dairy Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7976). Applied dairy science; emphasis on nutrition and management; herd health, labor-saving equipment, buildings, quality products, organization of dairy enterprise, business and economic aspects.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165, AN_SCI 3212, and AN_SCI 3232 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Dairy Production - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7976). Applied dairy science; emphasis on nutrition and management; herd health, labor-saving equipment, buildings, quality products, organization of dairy enterprise, business and economic aspects.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165, AN_SCI 3212, and AN_SCI 3232 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Horse Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7977). Systems of horse production: breeding, feeding and management of horses.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Swine Production
courses.description: Systems of pork production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred swine.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Swine Production - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Systems of pork production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred swine.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Poultry Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7979). Principles of housing systems, nutrition, management, business and production of commercial chickens and turkeys.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Poultry Production  Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 7979). Principles of housing systems, nutrition, management, business and production of commercial chickens and turkeys.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Animal Science
courses.description: Various courses offered on a preliminary basis to determine need for such offering prior to submission as a numbered course. Various topics, credit arranged.

courses.name: Pasture-Based Dairy Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4010). The objective of the class is to give a broad overview of pasture-based dairying and instill a confidence for students evaluating if this type of animal agriculture is an occupation they want to pursue after graduation. The class is taught by experts from various departments in CAFNR and covers elements of dairy and forage production needed to be successful.  Materials from this class are also cross-species related where information can be used on other ruminant type operations.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Background in dairy production, nutrition and reproductive physiology for Animal Science students or plant physiology and forage production for Plant Science students

courses.name: Monogastric Nutrition
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 7020 and NEP 7020; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4312 and NEP 4020). Principles of nutrition, feed formulation and recent research in poultry feeding. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physiology of Reproduction
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4314). Principles of animal reproduction with emphasis on endocrine control of reproductive processes.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 3254 and BIO_SC 1500 or equivalent; or AN_SCI 3254 as a co-requisite and instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Livestock Genetics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4323). Genetic principles applied to improvement of farm animals. Covers selection, prediction of genetic merit and mating systems.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500 and MATH 1100

courses.name: Genomics of Plants and Animals
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4323). Analysis of organisms at the level of the complete genome sequence.  Covers genome sequencing, assembly and annotation, as well as functional, evolutionary and computational genomics.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020 or BIO_SC 1500, MATH 1100, AN_SCI 3213 /PLNT_S 3213 or equivalent; and instructor's consent

courses.name: Ruminant Nutrition
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4332). Physiology, chemistry, microbiology and pathology of ruminants. Emphasizes the digestion, absorption, metabolism and utilization of nutrients.

courses.name: Processing Muscle Foods
courses.description: (same as F_S 7344; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4344, F_S 4344). Materials and technologies for the manufacture of muscle food products from red meats, poultry and seafood. Experience problem-solving through further processing of complex ingredients and develop skills by practicing operations in a pilot plant facility.

courses.name: Physiology and Biochemistry of Muscle as Food
courses.description: (same as F_S 7354; cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4354, F_S 4354). Basic concepts in muscle growth and development of livestock evaluating the effects of environment, welfare, nutrition and genetics regarding muscle metabolism, physiology, and the ultimate condition of muscle as food.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or equivalent or AN_SCI 3214 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Reproductive Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SC 4384). Reproductive management of cattle, swine and sheep; estrous synchronization; artificial insemination; embryo development and transfer; assisted reproductive technologies.

courses.name: Environmental Physiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4437). Principles of environmental physiology and animal adaptation with emphasis on mechanisms of temperature regulation and related nutritional and metabolic-hormonal functions.

courses.name: Beef Production and Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4975). Systems of beef production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred beef cattle.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Dairy Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4976). Applied dairy science; emphasis on nutrition and management; herd health, labor-saving equipment, buildings, quality products, organization of dairy enterprise, business and economic aspects.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2165, AN_SCI 3212 and AN_SCI 3232 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Horse Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4977). Systems of horse production: breeding, feeding and management of horses.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Swine Production
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 4978). Systems of pork production: breeding, feeding, management of commercial and purebred swine.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Poultry Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with AN_SCI 4979). Principles of housing systems, nutrition, management, business and production of commercial chickens and turkeys.
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 1065, AN_SCI 2175 and AN_SCI 3212 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Problems in Animal Science
courses.description: Advanced independent studies in fields not directly related to thesis or non-thesis degree research program. May be graded on S/U or A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Animal Science
courses.description: Critical consideration of research and other selected subjects in animal breeding, animal nutrition, reproductive physiology, growth and development and livestock production and management.

courses.name: Thesis Research in Animal Science
courses.description: Investigations in animal breeding, animal nutrition, reproduction physiology, growth and development livestock production and management.  Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Reproductive Biology Seminar
courses.description: Presentation and discussion of selected topics from all phases of reproductive biology. Open to qualified students of graduate standing in the field of Reproductive Biology.

courses.name: Meat Quality
courses.description: (same as F_S 8414). Discussion of factors affecting meat quality in beef, pork, lamb and poultry.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Survey of Epigenetics
courses.description: This course will introduce graduate students to the basic concepts in epigenetics, including DNA methylation, histone modifications, epigenetic modifiers/transacting factors, non-coding RNAs, genomic imprinting, and dosage compensation.  The course is designed to be a combination of lectures, paper discussions, and research talks by invited faculty speakers from across campus.

courses.name: Endocrinology
courses.description: Hormones of pituitary and endocrine glands; special reference to influence on growth, reproduction, milk secretion.

courses.name: Meat Investigations
courses.description: (same as F_S 8424). Discussions of scientific literature and hands-on experimentation with research techniques customarily used in the field of meat science.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics Programming
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 8430). This course provides the basics of programming and database development to students in the life sciences who have little prior programming experience. It covers Unix/Linux, Perl, MySQL, the relational database design process, and common data formats used in genome informatics. Students will learn how programming skills can enhance their ability to analyze large biological datasets, and will gain hands on experience with examples focused on genomics and bioinformatics. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Undergraduate or graduate course in Genetics

courses.name: Nutritional Biochemistry of Lipids
courses.description: (Same as NEP 8310 and NUTRIT 8310). Current concepts in the nutritional regulations of lipid metabolism. Emphasis on integrating information and interpreting current research data.

courses.name: Nutrient Regulation of Gene Expression
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8438, NEP 8438 and BIOCHM 8438). This second semester of the graduate nutritional sciences core curriculum will cover nutritional biochemistry of minerals and on research literature, with an emphasis on in-depth coverage of several minerals that illustrate emerging themes in mineral nutritional biochemistry and nutrient regulation of gene expression. The course will be taught in tutorial format.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 4270 and BIOCHM 4272 and 1st semester Graduate Nutrition core curriculum

courses.name: Livestock Production and Management Research Methods
courses.description: Techniques of experimentation, with application to livestock production and management. Exercises in methods of planning, conducting, analyzing, evaluating and reporting research.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4530/STAT 7530 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Functional Genomics of Mammalian Genomes: Focus on Microarray
courses.description: The curriculum covers methods for functional genomics.  It explores experimental designs, data filtering, ANOVA analysis, power calculations, clustering and classification systems, and functional annotation of genes through lectures, and bioinformatics and regular laboratories. May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 4974 and BIO_SC 4374 or equivalent courses, Anova analysis course (STAT 7530) or equivalent experience in using Anova analysis

courses.name: Recent Advances in Environmental and Endocrine Physiology
courses.description: Seminar. Presentation, discussion, and critical evaluation of current status of selected topics in environmental and endocrine physiology.

courses.name: Research in Animal Science
courses.description: Research in Animal Science

courses.name: Amino Acid Metabolism
courses.description: An in-depth study of amino acid metabolism and their relationship to animal nutrition.

courses.name: Molecular and Network Evolution
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8633). Evolution of biological macromolecules and networks, including sequence analysis algorithms and theory, phylogenetics, gene duplication, genome evolution, principles of biological networks. Development of computational skills emphasized.

courses.name: Science Outreach: Public Understanding of Science
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8725, PHYSCS 8350 and LTC 8725). Development of presentations to adult audiences on the science underlying issues of current interest.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Dissertation Research in Animal Science
courses.description: Investigations in animal breeding, animal nutrition, livestock production and management. Dissertation required. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Genetics of Populations
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative genetics with application to animal and plant breeding.

courses.name: Ruminant Nutrition
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8320). Physiology, chemistry, microbiology, pathology of ruminants. Emphasizes digestion, absorption, metabolism, utilization of nutrients. Lecture, laboratory, assigned readings.

courses.name: Gamete and Embryo Development
courses.description: A classical and molecular approach to spermatogenesis, oogenesis, fertilization and preimplantation development in the domestic species.

courses.name: Gonadal Function
courses.description: (same as BIOMED 9434).
courses.prerequisites: AN_SCI 4314, biochemistry or cell biology and AN_SCI 8420

courses.name: Placentation
courses.description: Provide students with current and in-depth information about the mechanisms involved in placental development and how the placenta (and placental products) influence maternal physiology - both locally at the placenta-uterine interface and systemically. All course topics will be covered in a comparative cross-species approach whenever possible. Emphasis will be placed on the most recent literature regarding the interactions taking place between the placenta and maternal system and how these interactions lead to the eventual birth of live young.
courses.recommendation: It is preferred that students take AN_SCI 9433 prior to this class, but this is not an absolute requirement

courses.name: Bioenergetics
courses.description: (same as NUTRIT 8400). Energetic interactions of animals and their physical and nutritional environments.

courses.name: Vitamins and Minerals
courses.description: Designed to provide students with an understanding of the chemical, metabolic, and functional role of vitamins and minerals in nutrition. While the primary focus will be on animals, comparative aspects to human nutrition will be discussed.

courses.name: Mycotoxins
courses.description: Designed to provide students with an understanding of the occurrence of mycotoxins, mechanisms of toxicity, analytical methodology, and approaches for ameliorating the toxic effects of mycotoxin in animals.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent and courses in Nutrition and Biochemistry
